case_vignette:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue and a change in his memory. The patient and his wife state that over the past several weeks the patient has been more confused and irritable and has had trouble focusing. He has had generalized and non-specific pain in his muscles and joints and is constipated. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 172/99 mmHg, pulse is 79/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 30%
Leukocyte count: 6,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 166,000/mm^3
MCV: 78 fL

Serum:
Na+: 141 mEq/L
Cl-: 103 mEq/L
K+: 4.6 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

No, there haven't been any recent changes in my work or personal life.

No, my diet and lifestyle have stayed the same.

No new changes in my medical history recently.

Yes, my blood pressure has been high.

No, my blood sugar levels have been stable.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The individual has been feeling extremely fatigued and has noticed changes in their memory. Their weight and appetite have remained stable, and they have not experienced any recent injuries or infections. Their sleep patterns and stress levels have not changed recently, and there have been no alterations in their family history, medication regimen, or work and personal life. Their diet and lifestyle have also remained consistent. There have been no recent changes in their medical history, however, the individual has reported high blood pressure. Their blood sugar levels have been stable, and they are not aware of any changes in their thyroid or liver function.
